evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including timing, involved personnel, and situational context.

slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or counter-evidence within the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_t2_interim period.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The environmental or marking deficiency should align with the key features and characteristics defined for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_t2_interim timeframe.

slot_statements.availability: Mechanical/control failure is present in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_t2_interim period.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: Mechanical/control failure in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim context is resistant to defeaters based on current evidence.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: Mechanical/control failure aligns with the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim dataset.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is observed and documented within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA aircraft during the 12-25 hist_t2_interim period.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 as documented in hist_t2_interim.

assumptions: Communication/coordination breakdown is indicated by lack of warnings and failure to stop pushback timely
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination preventing the incident
If procedural deviations better explain the event

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 and H8 document communication among crew and a lack of warning signals indicating a coordination breakdown during the pushback.
outcome.uncertainty_source: possible ambiguity in interpreting communication adequacy and coordination effectiveness

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure is present in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_t2_interim period.

assumptions: No direct mechanical fault evidence is present in the provided history.
Communication and procedural factors are sufficient to explain the incident.
defeaters: Direct evidence of mechanical or control system faults or malfunctions during the pushback would change the assessment.
Verified fault codes or repeat malfunctions indicating mechanical failure.

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H8, H1) indicates communication and procedural issues rather than mechanical/control failure, favoring communication breakdown or procedural deviation over mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of direct mechanical fault evidence; ambiguity in cause of pushback overrun

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 incident, including timing, involved personnel, and situational context.

No significant mechanical failures contributed to the event
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew at the time of the incident
If procedural deviations or mechanical failures better explained the event

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3 and H9 establish the crew roles and communication context; H2 and H8 show communication/coordination issues with ineffective signals and lack of warnings, supporting the claim of communication breakdown aligning with key features.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in distinguishing communication breakdown from procedural deviation; limited direct evidence on timing and situational context alignment

defeaters: If evidence showed that the TRP markings were missing, obscured, or not visible during the incident period, or if physical inspection confirmed marking deficiencies, the conclusion might change.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is observed and documented within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA aircraft during the 12-25 hist_t2_interim period.

assumptions: The TRP markings and their visibility were adequate as per H7
No mechanical control failure occurred as no evidence indicates such
defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical faults or tug control malfunctions
If communication breakdown was documented as preventing stop signals
If environmental markings were inadequate or not visible

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 documents the aircraft exceeding the TRP and hitting the blast barrier, indicating procedural deviation. H8 and H1-H3 show communication was ongoing but insufficient to prevent the deviation, supporting procedural deviation over communication breakdown or environmental causes. H7 and H9 confirm marker adequacy and trainee awareness, disfavoring environmental deficiency. No evidence of mechanical failure was found.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in communication effectiveness and signal visibility

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_t2_interim timeframe, reflecting typical patterns of deviation in this context.

assumptions: The TRP markings and their visibility were adequate as per H7.
The lack of warnings from wingman or headset operator indicates a procedural lapse rather than communication breakdown.
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication and warnings were given but ignored, or if environmental markings were inadequate or obscured, this would challenge the procedural deviation alignment.
If mechanical control faults were identified, that would shift the cause away from procedural deviation.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H4, H8, H9) shows the procedural deviation aligns with known key features: the pushback continued past the TRP despite visual signals and trained personnel, indicating typical procedural deviation rather than communication failure or environmental issues.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency should align with the key features and characteristics defined for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_t2_interim timeframe.

assumptions: The TRP marking described in H7 corresponds to the key features for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_t2_interim timeframe.
The tug instructor's statement in H8 reflects the actual effectiveness of communication signals during pushback.

If communication protocols or procedural compliance were clearly established and effective.

node.statement: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or counter-evidence within the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_t2_interim period.

assumptions: The TRP marking and clearance described in H7 were visible and unambiguous to the tug driver.
The visual stop signal method described in H8 is considered a procedural communication method rather than an environmental marking.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP marking was obscured or inadequate, or if the blast fence clearance was insufficient, this would challenge the environmental marking adequacy.
If communication or procedural compliance evidence indicated clear failure unrelated to marking, it might shift the cause away from environmental deficiency.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 confirms the presence and adequacy of the TRP marking and clearance, supporting environmental marking adequacy. H8 indicates that the visual stop signal method was insufficient and not perceived, suggesting procedural or communication issues rather than marking deficiency, thus supporting robustness against defeaters.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in whether the visual stop signal method is a procedural or environmental factor; limited direct evidence on marking visibility or condition.

children_spec.statement: Required environmental markings are present and visible
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect the aircraft and surrounding environment for presence and visibility of all required markings; absence or poor visibility lowers probability

children_spec.statement: Environmental conditions allow for proper visibility of markings

children_spec.test_procedure: Assess condition of markings for wear, dirt, or obstruction; poor maintenance or obscuration lowers probability

node.statement: The identification of procedural deviation in pushback execution for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during 12-25 hist_t2_interim is robust against potential defeaters, supported by consistent evidence and absence of contradictory data.

assumptions: Crew statements and observations are accurate and complete.
Environmental markings were visible and adequate as per H7.
No mechanical faults occurred as none were reported.
defeaters: If evidence emerged of communication failures between crew or headset operator warnings missed, or environmental markings being inadequate or obscured, this would challenge the procedural deviation conclusion.
Discovery of mechanical faults or tug equipment malfunction would also change the assessment.

node.statement: Environmental conditions allow for proper visibility of markings

assumptions: Visibility of TRP markings implies environmental conditions allowed proper visibility.
defeaters: If evidence showed obscured or damaged markings or poor lighting conditions reducing visibility.

node.statement: Communication systems on board were operational and available for use

defeaters: If evidence showed communication systems were non-operational or unavailable
If there was explicit confirmation that communication was effectively used to prevent the incident

However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1 confirms communication systems were operational and used, but H8 indicates communication signals were insufficient and no warnings were received, contradicting the claim that communication systems were effectively available for use to prevent breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in effectiveness of communication despite operational status

node.statement: Crew members were not reachable via standard communication devices during the incident

assumptions: Standard communication devices include the aircraft interphone and headset operator communications.
Lack of warnings from wingman or headset operator implies communication breakdown.
defeaters: If evidence showed active, effective communication warnings or alerts were exchanged among crew members during the incident.
If the headset operator or wingman had communicated timely warnings preventing the collision.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether communication devices were functional but ignored or truly unreachable

children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze communication logs and recordings for clarity, completeness, and absence of misunderstandings during pushback

children_spec.statement: Environmental conditions did not interfere with the proper execution of pushback procedures

node.statement: The pushback crew followed the standard operating procedures without unauthorized shortcuts

No direct evidence of procedural shortcuts was found in the provided history
defeaters: If evidence showed the crew ignored standard procedures or took unauthorized shortcuts during pushback
If communication or environmental factors were ruled out as causes

node.statement: Crew members were physically present and able to use communication devices when needed

defeaters: If evidence showed crew were unable to physically use communication devices or were absent, or if communication signals were effective and timely preventing incidents, the conclusion would change.

outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in effectiveness of communication despite physical presence and device availability

node.statement: Markings are maintained and not obscured or degraded

assumptions: Passing the TRP and hitting the blast barrier implies markings were not adequately maintained or visible.
Lack of warning signals and visual cues relates to marking/environmental deficiencies.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were clearly visible and not degraded or obscured, or if the collision was solely due to mechanical control failure or procedural error without marking issues.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 and H7 show the aircraft passed the TRP ground markings and hit the blast barrier, indicating markings were not effectively maintained or visible. H8 supports that visual signals were insufficient, implying marking or environmental deficiencies contributed.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the markings were physically degraded or simply not heeded; no explicit statement on marking condition

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t2_interim context is resistant to defeaters based on current evidence.

assumptions: No hidden mechanical faults exist beyond reported evidence
Operator statements accurately reflect the event and communication status
defeaters: Discovery of corroborated hardware faults or verified fault codes indicating mechanical failure
Evidence of procedural deviation by operators causing the failure
Physical marking or environmental deficiencies contributing to the event

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1-H3, H8) shows communication was active and no hardware faults were reported, supporting resistance to defeaters based on communication breakdown or procedural deviation.
outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of explicit hardware fault evidence; reliance on operator statements and communication logs

node.statement: Communication between the pushback crew and the flight deck was clear and unambiguous

defeaters: If evidence showed explicit, effective communication warnings were given and acknowledged during pushback
If the headset operator or wingman had clear line of sight and actively communicated impending hazards

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 directly states that the tug instructor did not receive any warning from the headset operator or wingman, indicating communication was not clear and unambiguous, contradicting the claim. H1 and H3 show communication channels existed but do not confirm clarity.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in communication effectiveness despite presence of communication channels

node.statement: Required environmental markings are present and visible

assumptions: Assuming that presence of TRP marking and clearance implies markings were visible and adequate.
defeaters: If evidence showed markings were obscured or missing, or if crew reported inability to see markings, the conclusion might change.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 indicates the TRP marking was present and visible with adequate clearance, contradicting the claim. Evidence H8 highlights communication and alerting failures rather than marking deficiencies, favoring a communication breakdown over marking issues.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether markings were truly visible to all crew members and whether communication failures overshadow marking adequacy.

children_spec.statement: Crew members were physically present and reachable during the event
children_spec.test_procedure: Check crew location logs, communication device status, and witness statements to confirm if crew members were available and reachable

children_spec.statement: Communication devices and channels were operational and accessible to the crew
children_spec.test_procedure: Review maintenance records, device logs, and test communication equipment functionality during the event timeframe

children_spec.statement: Crew members attempted to communicate or coordinate during the event
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze cockpit voice recordings, radio transmissions, and crew testimonies for evidence of communication attempts

children_spec.statement: No external factors prevented communication or coordination among crew
children_spec.test_procedure: Investigate environmental conditions, interference sources, or procedural restrictions that could have blocked communication

children_spec.statement: Mechanical components required for control are physically present and intact
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect the aircraft's mechanical control components for presence and physical integrity; absence or damage would lower availability

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are free from obstructions or blockages
children_spec.test_procedure: Check for any physical obstructions or blockages in the mechanical control pathways; detection of obstructions would reduce availability

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are properly connected and linked to control inputs
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify mechanical linkages and connections between control inputs and control surfaces; disconnections or misalignments would lower availability

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are free from wear or damage that impairs function
children_spec.test_procedure: Examine mechanical parts for wear, corrosion, or damage that could impair control function; presence of such issues would reduce availability

node.statement: Mechanical components required for control are physically present and intact

assumptions: Mechanical components would have been noted as damaged or malfunctioning if present
Operator and communication issues are sufficient to explain the event
defeaters: Direct evidence of mechanical component damage or malfunction during pushback
Bench checks or fault codes indicating mechanical control failure

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1-H4, H8) shows communication and operator actions were present but ineffective, indicating no mechanical/control failure; supports communication breakdown over mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of direct mechanical inspection or fault data

node.statement: Communication devices and channels were operational and accessible to the crew

defeaters: If evidence showed communication devices were malfunctioning or inaccessible
If crew reported inability to communicate during the event

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H3, H8, and H9 show communication devices and channels were operational and accessible, contradicting the claim of communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: none

node.statement: The pushback equipment was functioning correctly and did not contribute to procedural deviations

assumptions: No hidden or unreported equipment faults occurred
Descriptions of operator actions and equipment status are accurate and complete
defeaters: If evidence showed equipment malfunction or failure during pushback
If bench checks revealed control system faults

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 and H8 directly indicate the pushback equipment functioned correctly but procedural deviations by the operators led to the incident, supporting the claim that equipment was not at fault.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct mechanical fault evidence is presented; conclusions rely on absence of such evidence and operator behavior descriptions.

node.statement: Crew members attempted to communicate or coordinate during the event

defeaters: If evidence showed no communication attempts or explicit communication failure, or if mechanical failure was clearly the cause without coordination issues.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H2, H3, H8, and H9 directly describe communication attempts and coordination efforts among crew members during the event, supporting the claim that crew members attempted to communicate or coordinate.
outcome.uncertainty_source: None significant; evidence is direct and consistent.

node.statement: Environmental conditions did not interfere with the proper execution of pushback procedures

assumptions: The TRP markings and clearance described in H7 were visible and effective during the incident.
The trainee's awareness of the TRP implies environmental conditions did not hinder procedural compliance.
defeaters: If evidence showed poor visibility or inadequate markings at the TRP, or if environmental factors like weather or lighting had impaired the crew's ability to see or comply with procedures.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 shows adequate clearance and marking at the TRP, H9 confirms the trainee was aware of the TRP, and H8 indicates environmental signals were insufficient but not interfering, contradicting the claim that environmental conditions interfered with pushback procedures.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in the sufficiency of visual signals and possible unreported environmental factors

If physical inspection showed wear or damage impairing mechanical control function

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. node.statement: Relevant environmental data (weather, visibility, lighting) was unavailable or incomplete at the time of the incident

assumptions: The TRP marking visibility and environmental conditions were adequate as no evidence suggests otherwise.
Communication and alerting failures are distinct from environmental or marking deficiencies.
defeaters: If evidence showed that weather, visibility, or lighting conditions were poor or that markings were physically missing or obscured, this would support the claim.
If the headset operator or wingman had provided warnings or if the visual signals were adequate, the claim would be weakened.

defeaters: If evidence showed missing or improperly recorded markings in operational systems during the incident period, or if physical markings were confirmed absent or unclear.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. node.statement: Crew members were physically present and reachable during the event

defeaters: If evidence showed any crew member was absent or unreachable during the event, or communication was impossible.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H3, H8, and H9 directly indicate crew members (tug instructor, trainee driver, headset operator, wingman) were physically present and reachable during the event, supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: None significant; evidence clearly states physical presence and communication means.
